awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Sensing and Modeling Infrastructure for Storm Surge Monitoring and Forecasting in Coastal Zones
awd_abstract_narration:
The Atlantic Coast is threatened by disasterous storms every year. The dangers of high winds are widely publicized, but flooding has been responsible for more than half of all associated deaths. Unfortunately, existing forecasting capabilities are limited. Failure to predict significant flooding is of obvious concern, but the risks associated with perpetually inflated forecasts could be equally damaging. A citizen who evacuated Hurricane Irma's path based on storm surge warnings, only to return home to limited flooding, might consider ignoring future surge forecasts. Depending on the storm, that decision could be an enormous mistake. This project addresses surge forecasting limitations. 

The intellectual merit of this project lies in computer and network systems research and computational earth systems modeling research to be undertaken along two connected paths. First, the project will pursue the design, implementation, and evaluation of a fundamentally new approach to achieving high-precision in situ measurement of storm-induced surge in challenging environments. Second, the project will pursue fundamental extensions to an existing modeling system comprising coupled atmospheric, oceanic, and hydrologic models. The work will focus on assimilation of in situ surge measurements to anchor and refine model outputs prior to, during, and after tropical storms.

The broader impacts of this project will be significant: The world's coastal population is growing at an unprecedented rate. In the past four decades, the U.S. coastal population grew by 45%, with more than half of the population living in coastal counties. In the coming decades, coastal states' urban centers are expected to continue to grow. The resulting population density presents significant challenges. The ability of state and local governments to efficiently prepare for and respond to storm surge events is critical. This project will support significant progress toward the development of reliable storm surge monitoring and modeling systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This is an interdisciplinary effort that integrates sensors, computer science, machine learning, and earth science. The Coastal Carolina University team focused on the modeling aspect of the collaborative effort, while the Florida Atlantic University team worked on the smart drifter design and testing. The modeling work consists of creating and testing an atmosphere-ocean-river coupled model system that can integrate unique micro-drifter sensor data and predict hurricane-induced storm surge, inundation, and inland flooding to assist in disaster mitigation and emergency management strategic planning for the coastal community. In addition, assimilation of the data obtained by the micro-drifter sensors into the aforesaid modeling system and evaluation of the data's enhancement of storm surge monitoring and forecast skills.

 

intellectual merit

We conducted a combined theoretical and numerical investigation of the input data fields required for computing the flood risk index in order to estimate the possible storm surge height and flooding area caused by oncoming landfall storms. Such a strategy is derived using simplified 2-D shallow water equations.

In an interdisciplinary study involving computer science, social science, and geophysical science, we investigated the design of a combined physical sensor- and social sensor-based information framework to collect heterogeneous flooding disaster data, fuse that data, and generate actionable understandings.

The atmosphere-ocean-river model developed for this project was used to investigate a historical compound storm in which two hurricanes – Floyd and Dennis in 1999 – hit the same location consecutively. Our analysis of historical observational data and model simulations revealed a "downstream blocking" mechanism responsible for extensive coastal and inland flooding, as well as significant loss of life and property caused by these two hurricanes.

Machine-learning-based Artificial intelligence (AI) was combined with a computer model to help assimilate micro-drifter data and improve the accuracy of the computer model's predicted drifter float paths. The AI model is made up of the convolutional neural network and the gated recurrent unit. The ground truth data used for training, testing, and verifying the AI model came from the Ocean of Things (OoT) program of the United States' Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), which deployed hundreds of micro drifters into the ocean and tracked their movements. The results show that after the AI correction, 82.0% of the computer model predicted paths of floats were improved, and the overall error was reduced by 57.49%, indicating the effectiveness of using artificial intelligence to assimilate micro drifter data to improve coastal ocean modeling and prediction. 

Broader impacts

This interdisciplinary research has implications for network systems, artificial intelligence, and computational geophysical modeling. In the first field, this project produces a new type of smart drifter with sensors capable of making high-precision in-situ measurements of storm surge-related variables. We developed a machine learning algorithm for the second area that reduced the drifter trajectory prediction error by more than 50%. In the third field, the development of a sophisticated coupled computer model system and its incorporation of smart drifter sensors can significantly improve hurricane-induced storm surge and inundation forecast performance and advance the field of numerical weather prediction (NWP).

Furthermore, the project helps to bridge the traditionally disconnected physical science and social science through computer science technology by designing and proposing a framework in which the fusion of physical sensor- and social sensor-based information helps understand impending events and conditions detrimental to lives and properties, enabling the resilience of smart and connected communities.

The primary goal of this project, which is to improve storm surge and inundation forecasting by combining smart drifter sensor data and a coupled computational geo-physical model system, will have an impact on the Southeastern Atlantic coastal region as well as coastal communities worldwide that are affected by tropical cyclone-induced storm surge and inundation. This project's more accurate and timelier forecast guidance will make government agencies and communities more efficient and effective in their emergency management activities, potentially saving lives and property.
